answer:
**Frame‐by‐Frame Analysis**  
• **Frame 1:** The roadway is fairly clear; the cyclist is straight ahead. No obvious runner in shorts is visible near center frame.  
• **Frame 2 & Frame 3:** Still no clear sign of the running pedestrian; the cyclist is nearer the center of the roadway.  
• **Frame 4:** A runner (t‐shirt and shorts) appears to the right of the cyclist, entering the crosswalk area on the driver’s right side of center.  
• **Frame 5:** The same runner is now nearer the middle/left portion of the crosswalk, clearly moving across the road toward the driver’s left.

**Contextual Reasoning**  
From Frame 4 to Frame 5, the pedestrian is running across the lanes from the right side of the driver’s viewpoint to the left side. The cyclist continues forward, whereas the runner cuts across the road, indicating a right‐to‐left crossing relative to the dashcam (ego) perspective.

**Match to Answer Choices**  
• (A) & (B) – Not moving along the road in the same or opposite direction; the pedestrian is crossing, not running along the lane.  
• (C) – “Left to right” contradicts the frames, since the pedestrian starts on the driver’s right and finishes on the left.  
• (D) – “From right to left” accurately reflects the directional transition visible in Frames 4 and 5.

<answer>D</answer>
